citeinfo.origin: Gerald Sanger, National Marine Fisheries Service (NMFS), National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA)
citeinfo.title: Fishery Potentials and Estimated Biological Productivity of the Subarctic Pacific Region

abstract.p: Pertinent literature on the primary production and fishery potentials of the Subarctic Pacific region are reviewed. An original estimate of the annual primary production of the region (1.28 x 10 to the 9th tons C/year) is derived and relations of present fish production with estimated potential biological productivity are discussed.

Assuming a simplified food chain relation for biological production, the potential fish production (not harvest) of the Region is estimated at 26-78 million tons/yr. Assuming 50% is potentially harvestable, the current average landings (6.6 million tons/yr) would have to be increased four-fold to equal this potential.
The scarcity of reliable basic information on oceanic ecology, essential for studies such as this, is briefly discussed.

[Reference: Sanger, Gerald A. Fishery Potentials and Estimated Biological Productivity of the Subarctic Pacific Region. in A. Y. Takenouti, A. Y., ed. Biological oceanography of the northern North Pacific Ocean. Dedicated to Dr. Sigeru Motoda in commemoration of his contribution to marine biology. Tokyo, Idemitsu Shoten, 1972.] Reprint available at the NOAA Seattle NMML Library.

descript.purpose: Collected data revealing Fishery potentials and estimated biological productivity of the Subarctic Pacific region
